engineering_design_principles.mechanism: The pancreas serves as a central regulatory organ maintaining optimal glucose levels in the bloodstream through the release of hormones such as insulin and glucagon.
Cells within the islets of Langerhans specialize in the production and secretion of specific hormones, triggering precise physiological responses to maintain glucose homeostasis.
The pancreas is geometrically designed as both an exocrine and endocrine gland, allowing it to perform dual functions in hormonal regulation and digestive enzyme production.
The islets of Langerhans resemble a well-designed engineering system, with individual components specializing in specific tasks for efficient hormonal regulation.

The exocrine portion of the pancreas is composed of acinar cells arranged in a branching ductal structure, akin to an intricate plumbing system, facilitating the transport of digestive enzymes into the small intestine.
